title: How to Fix Your Maytag Dryer's Start Button
author: PartSelect Team
content:
PartSelect Blog
        
        
            All Topics
        
    

    
            
            
    

    

	
		
			Save
		
		
			
				
					How to Fix Your Maytag Dryer's Start Button
					Start your Maytag dryer again, today!
				
				
					


    
        
            Post			
        
    

    
        
            Pin It			
        
    

    
        
            Share			
        
    

    
        
            Subscribe
        
    

				

				
					Page content+Why Your Maytag Dryer Won't StartWhy won't my Maytag dryer start, even with power?Why is nothing happening when I push my Maytag dryer's start button?Why won't my Maytag dryer start, but it clicks?How do I reset my Maytag dryer?+How to Fix a Maytag Dryer That Won't StartHow to Replace a Maytag Dryer Start Button if it Won't StartHow to Replace a Maytag Dryer Door Switch if it Won’t StartHow to Replace a Maytag Dryer Door Latch if it Won’t StartHow to Replace a Maytag Dryer Thermal Fuse if it Won’t StartHow to Replace a Maytag Dryer Belt if it Won’t StartHow to Replace a Maytag Dryer Control Board if it Won’t StartIf your Maytag dryer won't start when you push its start button, or if it's having starting issues that are confusing you, don't worry, we have the answers. A Maytag dryer that won't start is usually caused by a bad push-to-start or door switch, door latch, thermal fuse, belt, or control board, and can be fixed relatively quickly with only a few tools!

Why Your Maytag Dryer Won't Start
Not every Maytag dryer has the same starting issues, so laying out all of the most frequently asked questions for you to figure out where to start gives you the best chance of fixing your dryer's issue as soon as possible, and getting your wet clothes dry.

Why won't my Maytag dryer start, even with power?
A Maytag dryer not starting when you push its start button can be a sign that the start button is bad and in need of replacing, but the following list of parts may also be bad or faulty, and not only causing your dryer starting issues, but are also in need of replacing:
Bad Push-to-Start Switch
Bad Door Switch
Broken Door Latch
Blown or Faulty Thermal Fuse
Broken Dryer Belt
Faulty or Bad Control Board


Why is nothing happening when I push my Maytag dryer's start button?
If your Maytag dryer isn't starting after selecting the cycle and pressing the start button, there's usually an underlying issue at hand with the start button itself or another part. For example, if the start button is broken or bad it won't tell the control board to start the drying cycle, and your dryer will not start.

Why won't my Maytag dryer start, but it clicks?
A clicking sound coming from your dryer when it won't start indicates a bad or faulty thermostat within the dryer. The 'clicking' noise can be many things, but is normally the thermostat opening and closing, which is usually an indication that it needs to be replaced.

How do I reset my Maytag dryer?
Many Maytag dryer models do not have a dedicated reset button like other manufacturers, however, an easy way to reset your Maytag dryer, or any appliance for that matter, is to unplug it. Once you've unplugged it, let it sit for 5-10 minutes before plugging it in again and starting a dryer cycle. Doing this performs a hard reset, and if your dryer doesn't work after performing one, it means your issue lies with it parts.

How to Fix a Maytag Dryer That Won't Start
If resetting your Maytag dryer didn't work, your dryer issues are definitely with the parts of the dryer itself. As mentioned above, this may be a simple push-to-start switch, or could be replacing the entire dryer belt. In any case, we have the guide you need to fix your Maytag dryer today!

How to Replace a Maytag Dryer Start Button if it Won't Start
The central place to start with any sort of dryer starting issue is its start button - whether it's the button itself or the switch that actually communicates with the control board, one is clearly not working and needs to be replaced with an OEM Maytag dryer start button switch.



First, disconnect your dryer's power cord from its wall outlet.
Then locate your dryer's push-to-start button.
Pull your dryer away from the wall.
Using a Philips-head screwdriver, unthread and disconnect the back panel of the dryer.
Take note of any wires for future installation reference.
Remove the button and then the wire harness from the current switch.
Use a screwdriver to dislodge the current switch and remove it from its installation location.
From here, you can use a multimeter to test the switch for continuity, or you can replace it outright.
To install the new switch, push it into place and rotate it if necessary to secure it.
Install the wire harness into the new switch, and replace the back cover of the dryer.
Plug your dryer back into the wall outlet, and attempt to run a short test cycle. If the dryer does not start, the push-to-start switch is not the central issue.



How to Replace a Maytag Dryer Door Switch if it Won’t Start
If the push-to-start switch in your Maytag dryer is not the source of your dryer's starting issues, the door switch can certainly lend itself to many starting issues. A bad door switch will cause the control board not to recognize when the door has been shut so it can properly start. However, replacing a dryer door switch is easy with a few tools and the right OEM dryer door switch for your Maytag dryer model!



Disconnect your dryer from its wall outlet.
Depending on your dryer model, you will need to remove the top-mounted lint screen.
Open your dryer door and locate its door switch.
Use a putty knife and screwdriver to dislodge the top panel of the dryer.
Locate the door switch on the side of the dryer, and use a screwdriver to disconnect its wire harness.
Use your screwdriver to unthread the mounting bracket of the switch from the front of the dryer.
Remove the old switch, and now you can test it with a multimeter to test for continuity. If it shows signs of continuity, it is not causing the starting issues.
With the new or existing switch, install it into the appropriate wire harness and mounting bracket.
Reconnect the top of the dryer and thread all necessary screws back into the dryer.
Install the lint-screen back into the dryer.
Plug your dryer back in and run a short cycle. If it does not start, the door switch is not causing the starting problems.



How to Replace a Maytag Dryer Door Latch if it Won’t Start
If your dryer won't start, it may be the result a broken door latch not communicating to the control board that the door is closed. A dryer's door latch can break if the door is closed too aggressively, or simply over time due to wear and tear. However, it can also be easily replaced with a few tools, an OEM door latch made for your Maytag dryer model, and the guide to show you how to replace it!



Disconnect your dryer from the wall outlet.
Open the dryer door and locate the door latch.
Inspect the door latch for any damage or broken pieces. If you notice either of those, it will need to be replaced.
To replace the dryer door latch, use a screwdriver to gain access to the latch itself; this may involve dislodging a plastic panel within the frame. This may also require you to use your screwdriver to unthread certain pieces, which will need to be rethreaded later.
Once any plastic panels are removed, use a screwdriver to remove the old door latch and install the new one.
Ensure the new door latch is secure and reinstall any plastic panel covers.
Place clothes in the dryer and attempt to start a dryer load. If the dryer doesn't start, the door latch is not causing the starting problems.



How to Replace a Maytag Dryer Thermal Fuse if it Won’t Start
Thermal fuses are designed to cut off power to the heating element and dryer as a whole if the internal temperature exceeds the safety limit. If your Maytag dryer isn't starting, it very well could be a case of a thermal fuse that's been activated or potentially defective. But what's important is you can replace a thermal fuse easily with a few tools, a new OEM thermal fuse for your Maytag dryer model, and a step-by-step guide to show you the whole process.



Disconnect your dryer from its wall outlet. For this repair, it's important you wear protective gloves.
Use a screwdriver to unthread and remove the back panel of the dryer.
Locate the thermal fuse within the dryer cabinet. This may be near the exhaust duct or the blower housing, both of which will likely be near the bottom rear of the cabinet.
Disconnect the wire harness connected to the thermal fuse, and now you can use a multimeter to test it for continuity or just replace it. If it shows signs of continuity, move on to the next part. But if it does not show continuity, you will need to replace it.
Unthread and remove the old thermal fuse and install the new one in its place.
Connect the necessary wire harness and secure the new fuse.
Replace the back panel cover of your dryer, and connect the plug to your wall outlet.
Attempt to run a cycle in the dryer, and if it doesn't start, it is not the cause of your problems.



How to Replace a Maytag Dryer Belt if it Won’t Start
The dryer belt is arguably the most important part of a dryer, since it is what rotates the drum inside the cabinet. If the belt is broken or damaged, the dryer drum will stop rotating and may even cause the dryer not to start, and will need to be replaced. All you need to replace a Maytag dryer belt are a few tools, a new OEM belt made for your Maytag dryer model, and the following guide to show you how to replace it.



First, disconnect your dryer from the wall outlet.
If your dryer has a top-mounted lint screen, remove it.
Use a putty knife and/or screwdriver to disconnect the top panel of the dryer.
Disconnect any wire harnesses within the top of the dryer cabinet. Make sure to take pictures of any wires for future installation reference.
Use your screwdriver to unthread and disconnect the dryer's front panel, and then remove it. Depending your model, you may also need to remove wire harnesses in the door, as well as removing the door itself.
Now, locate the dryer drum belt and investigate it for any damage or breaks. If it is still in good working condition, you can reassemble your dryer.
If your dryer belt is broken or damaged, it's important that you replace it.
Locate the idler pulley underneath the dryer drum and carefully disconnect the belt from it.
Lift the dryer drum and remove the old belt.
Install the new belt underneath the drum and carefully into the idler pulley.
Install the dryer's front panel, as well as any wire harness originally connected to it, as well as a the door if that was removed.
Reinstall any necessary wire harnesses at the top portion of the dryer cabinet.
Install the top portion of the dryer, and ensure it is secured with the appropriate screws.
Install the lint screen and any screws at the top of the dryer if applicable.
Connect your dryer to the wall outlet and start a new cycle. If it still does not start, you need to replace the control board.



How to Replace a Maytag Dryer Control Board if it Won’t Start
If you're having any sort of starting issue with your dryer, and no other parts are responsible, the control board is usually the last part to be replaced considering it's the brains of your dryer. If your Maytag dryer's control board is not working properly and is bad or shorted, it needs to be replaced immediately. Everything you would need to replace a Maytag dryer's control board are a new OEM control board itself, as well as a few tools, and a handy guide!



Disconnect your dryer from its wall outlet.
Depending on your dryer model, you may have a control board on the top or front of your cabinet. Use a screwdriver to remove the back panel of the dryer if it is a top-mounted model, and remove the top panel if it's a front-mounted model.
Locate the control board take any photos of the wires and their connections for future reference.
Disconnect the wire harnesses connected to the control board. Now you can use a multimeter to test the control board for any shorts or defects. Use your model's user manual to verify the correct specifications for continuity and whether it needs to be replaced.
Connect the wire harnesses from your dryer to the new board.
Install the new control board within your dryer.
Reinstall the top and/or back panel of your dryer, and ensure all of the dryer's screw connections are secure.
You can now run a test cycle on your dryer to ensure all components are working properly.



At this point, your dryer should be working well, and your clothes are hopefully getting drier as you're reading this! If not, you may have a more serious underlying issue that will require Maytag technical support. And should you need appliance assistance or inspiration within your home in the future, be sure to check out our other appliance error code and home improvement guides over at the  PartSelect blog! And for all of the parts you need for the appliances you rely on and use everyday, go to PartSelect.com!

title: How to Replace an LG Refrigerator's Water Filter
author: PartSelect Team
content:
PartSelect Blog
        
        
            All Topics
        
    

    
            
            
    

    

	
		
			Save
		
		
			
				
					How to Replace an LG Refrigerator's Water Filter
					What you need for good tasting and smelling water!
				
				
					


    
        
            Post			
        
    

    
        
            Pin It			
        
    

    
        
            Share			
        
    

    
        
            Subscribe
        
    

				

				
					Page content+How to Replace the Different Types of LG Refrigerator Water FiltersInline Water FilterTwist to Remove Water FilterPull Down Water Filter+Frequently Asked Questions About Water FiltersAre generic water filters OK to use?How often do I need to change my LG refrigerator's water filter?Can you replace an LG refrigerator water filter without turning off water?How do I reset my LG refrigerator after installing a new water filter?If the water from your LG refrigerator has a funny taste or smell to it, it's likely a sign that the water filter is in dire need of replacing. After all, water filters are used to remove any chemicals or minerals that would be unhealthy to drink, like chlorine, VOCs (volatile organic compounds), and many more. Which is why we're going to show you exactly how to replace an LG refrigerator's water filter, and answer some popular questions along the way.

How to Replace the Different Types of LG Refrigerator Water Filters
Although there are quite a few different models and types of LG refrigerators, they all borrow from a shared pool of water filters. Speaking of, you can find the water filter for your LG refrigerator in PartSelect's water filter finder! Each of these filter types all serve the same purpose, in filtering out harsh chemicals, contaminants, and unpleasant tasting minerals, but they all require different ways of removing and installing. Before replacing any water filter, ensure your water line supply is shut and turned off.

Inline Water Filter
Inline water filters are installed outside of your refrigerator and are designed to allow the water line to flow inline through it, on its way to the refrigerator. The most common LG refrigerators that use inline water filters are top freezer models.


For this replacement, you will require a bucket and a towel.
Locate an inline water filter behind the fridge. It is normally mounted to the wall or the fridge itself.
Your filter will have two water lines going into each end of the filter, with a grommet securing each tube. Carefully remove the tubes from each end.
Take the new filter and plug the water supply line into one end.
Now turn your water supply on and flush 2.5 gallons of water through the filter to flush and prime it. Once finished, turn off the water supply.
Then, install the fridge's water line into the filter.
To ensure the filter is installed correctly, if you pull slightly on each line, the line should stay inside the filter.
Install the filter to your wall or refrigerator mount, and turn on the water supply.



Twist to Remove Water Filter
Twist to remove water filters are normally located in the top left or top right portion of your French 3 or 4 door, side-by-side, or top freezer refrigerator, or in its door.


Pull the tray of the water filter out if applicable, and allow the filter to swing out or down.
Grab the filter and turn it counterclockwise until it disconnects and comes out of the filter housing.
Take the new filter and place it in the filter housing, then rotate it clockwise until it's secure.
If your filter has a housing or tray, push it into place and close the housing.
Now, turn on the water supply to the refrigerator and dispense 2.5 gallons of water to flush and prime the filter.



Pull Down Water Filter
If your refrigerator has a pull down water filter, you will normally locate it in French 3 or 4 door, or side-by-side models of refrigerators.


Locate the water filter in the top right or top left of the refrigerator cabinet.
Open the water filter tray, and the water filter should swing out.
Pull the water filter down carefully and it should simply come out.
With your new water filter in hand, push it into the filter housing, and swing it upwards towards the fridge ceiling.
Close the water filter tray, and turn on the water supply.
Flush 2.5 gallons of water through the water dispenser to get the filter primed and ready to be used.



Frequently Asked Questions About Water Filters
When replacing the water filter in your LG refrigerator, there are some common misconceptions and things that are popularly misunderstood - and we're hoping that these frequently asked questions will clear up anything you're curious about!

Are generic water filters OK to use?
Generic and non-OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) filters are not suitable for use for most appliances and equipment, especially not refrigerators. OEM water filters require much less maintenance, are designed to work specifically with your refrigerator model, and because they are made and supplied directly from the original manufacturer, and thus go through the same quality testing, they also typically last much longer.

How often do I need to change my LG refrigerator's water filter?
You need to replace your LG refrigerator's water filter once every 6 months, or as needed. It's important to look for taste differences in the water, an indicator that will light around the time the filter needs to be replaced, or a significantly lower level of water pressure from the dispenser.

Can you replace an LG refrigerator water filter without turning off water?
When replacing the water filter for your LG refrigerator, it's important to disengage and turn off the water line to ensure a large amount of excess water does not come out from the water filter port when replacing it.

How do I reset my LG refrigerator after installing a new water filter?
Once your water filter for your LG refrigerator has been replaced with a new one, you can easily reset the water filter light indicator by holding the 'Reset Filter' button for 3-5 seconds, until the light turns off.

Now that you've replaced the water filter in your LG refrigerator, you're able to enjoy tasty and contaminant-free water! Remember that water filters need to replaced on a regular basis, and at the very most should be replaced after 6-8 months of regular use. However, if you use your refrigerator's built-in water dispenser more or less often than average, you may be looking at a different lifespan for your new filter.

title: How to Get Rid of Air Conditioner Smells
author: PartSelect Team
content:
PartSelect Blog
        
        
            All Topics
        
    

    
            
            
    

    

	
		
			Save
		
		
			
				
					How to Get Rid of Air Conditioner Smells
					Top 7 Most Common Smells and Fixes
				
				
					


    
        
            Post			
        
    

    
        
            Pin It			
        
    

    
        
            Share			
        
    

    
        
            Subscribe
        
    

				

				
					Page content+Air Conditioner Smells like Mold or MildewHow to Clean the Air Conditioner Drain Pan+Air Conditioner Smells like Socks or Dirty FeetHow to Clear a Blocked Condensate Line+Air Conditioner Smells MustyHow to Clean the Air Conditioner Air Filters+Air Conditioner Smells like Rotten EggsHow to Remove a Dead Animal From Ducts+Air Conditioner Smells like SmokeHow to Clean the Evaporator CoilAir Conditioner Smells like Skunk or GasAir Conditioner Smells like Exhaust FumesIf your air conditioner smells like mold or dirty socks/feet, you will need to check the drain pan for stagnant water and the condensate line for a blockage. If it smells like rotten eggs, there is likely a dead animal stuck in the ductwork, which you will need to remove. If the unit smells musty, the air filters are either clogged or need to be replaced. Smelling exhaust fumes is a sign that the circuit or wiring is burnt, while smelling smoke indicates that the evaporator coils need to be cleaned. If the air conditioner smells like skunk spray or sulfur this is an indication of a gas leakage and you will need to turn off the gas and call your service provider immediately. Whether you have a window or portable air conditioner, you can use this guide to learn practical tips and techniques for identifying, addressing, and preventing these common air conditioner smells.  

Air Conditioner Smells like Mold or Mildew
If your air conditioner smells like mold it is likely due to moisture buildup within the unit, which creates an ideal environment for mold and mildew growth. As warm air passes over the evaporator coil, moisture in the air condenses on the cold coil and forms water droplets. This water then drips down into a drain pan located beneath the evaporator coil. To get rid of this smell you will need to thoroughly clean the drain pan, which is the part responsible for holding water produced by the AC until is drained out. If you own a portable air conditioner, you will typically need to empty the drain pan manually each time it reaches capacity in order to keep it clean and prevent the growth of mold and bacteria.

How to Clean the Air Conditioner Drain Pan

Before starting any maintenance on your air conditioner disconnect the power supply for your safety.
Remove the access panel or front cover of the AC to access the drain pan which is typically found beneath the evaporator coil.
If there's standing water in the drain pan, use towels to remove it. Be careful not to spill water onto electrical components.
Mix a solution of warm water and mild detergent or dish soap in a bucket. Alternatively, you can use a mixture of water and vinegar for natural disinfecting properties.
Use a soft brush or sponge to gently scrub the drain pan until you have removed all traces of contaminants. 
Rinse it with clean water to remove any remaining soap or debris.
For added disinfection, you can spray the drain pan with a mixture of water and bleach.
Allow the bleach solution to sit for a few minutes before rinsing thoroughly with clean water.
Use a clean towel or allow the drain pan to air dry completely before reinstalling it.
Once the drain pan is clean and dry, reassemble the air conditioner and reconnect the power supply.


Air Conditioner Smells like Socks or Dirty Feet
An unpleasant odor that smells like dirty socks or feet is caused by stagnant water in the drain pan. Window air conditioners have a condensate line, which is a pipe or tube that is responsible for removing excess moisture, or condensate, from the air conditioner. It carries water out of the drain pan and disposes of it outside the home. A clogged condensate drain line will be unable to carry out this function leading to water collecting in the pan and not draining out. A clogged condensate line may also cause water in the drain pan to overflow. This can result in water damage to the air conditioner and surrounding areas, therefore, it is important to address the problem as soon as possible.
 
How to Clear a Blocked Condensate Line

Turn off the power to the air conditioning system before beginning any repairs.
Locate the condensate line which typically runs from the air conditioner's indoor unit to the outside of your home. It may also connect to a drain or a condensate pump.
Inspect the condensate line for any visible signs of blockage or bends which may restrict the flow of water.
You can use your hands, a brush, or a small plumbing snake to clear the blockage.
Once the line is clear, you can clean it by flushing it with a mixture of equal parts vinegar and water.
Once you've cleared the blockage, turn on the air conditioner and monitor the condensate line for proper drainage. You should see water flowing freely from the line to the drain or outside of your home.


Air Conditioner Smells Musty
A musty air conditioner smell is one of the most common unpleasant smells that many owners experience. It is typically caused by dirty air filters. The air filter in both window and portable units is responsible for trapping dust, and other contaminants from entering the air conditioner to keep the air fresh and protect various internal components in your unit from damage. Over time it is common for the air filters to accumulate and become obstructed by dust and debris. It is recommended to regularly clean them to allow fresh air to circulate properly and keep the unit running efficiently.

How to Clean the Air Conditioner Air Filters

Begin by disconnecting the air conditioner from the power supply.
Remove the grille or cover on the unit to access the filters. 
Depending on your air conditioner you may be able to simply pull out the filter or you may first need to remove the air filter cover if one is present.
If the filters are damaged or no longer in good condition, you will likely need to replace the air filter to fix your air conditioner.
Rinse the filter under warm water to clear off any dirt or debris. Avoid using hot water, as this can damage the filter material. You can also use a vacuum cleaner with a brush attachment to gently remove the dust from the filters.
If the filters are particularly dirty, you can use a mild detergent solution to help remove stubborn stains or buildup. 
After cleaning, allow the filters to air dry completely before reinstalling them in the air conditioner. Ensure they are thoroughly dry to prevent mold or mildew growth.
Once the filters are dry, carefully slide them back into place or reattach them to the unit, ensuring they are positioned correctly and securely.
Restore power to the air conditioner and check that it is running properly.
To maintain optimal performance, it's recommended to clean or replace air conditioner filters every 1 to 3 months, depending on usage and environmental factors.


Air Conditioner Smells like Rotten Eggs
If you smell rotten eggs coming from your air conditioner, this is an indication that there may be a dead animal inside the ductwork in your home. Unfortunately, it is common for small animals such as birds and rodents to get trapped inside the ducts. However, even if you have a ductless air conditioner, smaller animals such as lizards may still find their way inside the unit and become trapped there. You will need to inspect and remove any foreign materials inside the unit to get rid of the smell. 

How to Remove a Dead Animal From Ducts

Put on gloves, a mask, and safety glasses to protect yourself from any potential contaminants or pathogens associated with handling dead animals.
Use a screwdriver to remove the screws securing the vent cover or access panel.
Inspect the ductwork for any obstructions or a dead animal. If you are sure there is an animal but you are unable to reach it, you should call in a professional pest removal company.
If you can reach the animal, carefully pull it from the ductwork using gloved hands or a pair of tongs. Be careful not to touch the carcass with your bare hands as this may pose a health risk.
Place the carcass in a sealed plastic bag or container and dispose of it at an approved waste disposal site. 
Thoroughly clean and disinfect the area of the ductwork where you found the dead animal. You can use a mixture of bleach and water to sanitize the area and remove any remaining odor.

 
Air Conditioner Smells like Smoke
If you smoke in your home or near the outdoor unit, then eventually your air conditioner will begin to smell like stale cigarette smoke. This is because certain components in your air conditioner, such as the evaporator coil, absorb the odor from the smoke and then circulate it through the vents whenever you are using the air conditioner. To avoid the smell of smoke it is best to clean the evaporator coil and also avoid smoking in or near your home.

How to Clean the Evaporator Coil

Remove the cover or front panel of the air conditioner to access the evaporator coil.
If the evaporator coil is covered by an access panel, use a screwdriver to remove it as well.
Use a soft-bristled brush or a coil cleaning brush to gently remove dirt and debris from the coil fins. Be careful to avoid bending or damaging the fins, as this can restrict airflow and reduce system efficiency.
Apply coil cleaner to the evaporator coil according to the manufacturer's instructions.
Allow the coil cleaner to sit on the coils for the recommended time as this allows the cleaner to penetrate and loosen stubborn dirt and debris.
Rinse the evaporator coil thoroughly with clean water.
Once the coil is dry, reassemble the access panel and front cover of the air conditioner and secure it in place. 
Turn the power back on to your air conditioning system and test it to ensure proper operation.


 Air Conditioner Smells like Skunk or Gas
If your air conditioner smells like skunk or sulfur, this is a sign of a potentially dangerous situation in your home that requires immediate attention. This smell is usually a sign of a gas leakage, specifically one known as methyl mercaptan. If you detect this smell, promptly turn off the gas supply to your home, leave the area, and contact your gas provider immediately.

Air Conditioner Smells like Exhaust Fumes
An air conditioner that smells like exhaust fumes or like something is burning is typically caused by a burnt circuit board or wiring. If you suspect there are electrical issues in the air conditioner, it is essential to have the system inspected by a qualified technician to prevent safety hazards.
This smell may also be caused by leaking refrigerant. Refrigerant is a cooling agent that helps to keep your air conditioner running efficiently. Over time the refrigerant can corrode due to exposure to moisture, or chemicals, or it may become damaged or loose. If the refrigerant line is damaged or faulty, it may cause the refrigerant to leak out. It is best to call a professional technician to address this issue promptly as it can be hazardous to your health. 
 
Understanding the causes behind the odors coming from your air conditioner is the first step towards effectively eliminating them and restoring a fresh, comfortable indoor environment. If you follow the steps laid out in this article, you will be well-equipped with the knowledge and tools needed to conquer air conditioner smells once and for all.

title: Why Your Whirlpool Washer Won’t Spin
author: PartSelect Team
content:
PartSelect Blog
        
        
            All Topics
        
    

    
            
            
    

    

	
		
			Save
		
		
			
				
					Why Your Whirlpool Washer Won’t Spin
					DIY Tips to Fix a Non-Spinning Whirlpool Washer
				
				
					


    
        
            Post			
        
    

    
        
            Pin It			
        
    

    
        
            Share			
        
    

    
        
            Subscribe
        
    

				

				
					Page contentSigns Your Whirlpool Washer Isn't Spinning Properly+Troubleshooting and Fixing a Whirlpool Washer That Won’t SpinThings to Check on a Whirlpool Washer That Won’t SpinHow to Troubleshoot the Lid Switch on a Whirlpool Washer That Won’t SpinHow to Troubleshoot the Door Latch on a Whirlpool Washer That Won’t SpinHow to Troubleshoot the Drive Belt on a Whirlpool Washer That Won’t SpinHow to Troubleshoot the Drain Hose on a Whirlpool Washer That Won’t SpinWhether it's water not draining, clothes remaining soaking wet, or unusual noises during operation, a non-spinning Whirlpool washer may have a defective door latch or lid switch, a displaced drive belt, or a blocked drain hose. In this article, we'll walk you through troubleshooting and fixing these common problems step by step.

Signs Your Whirlpool Washer Isn't Spinning Properly
Dealing with a Whirlpool washer that refuses to spin can be a real head-scratcher. You may notice these warning signs when this happens:

Water Not Draining: If you find water lingering in the drum after a wash cycle, it's a strong indication that your washer's draining system isn't functioning correctly.
Clothes Still Soaking Wet: When your freshly washed laundry comes out of your washer dripping wet, it may be linked to an imbalanced load which prevented your washer from wringing out excess water.
Heavier Loads Aren't Cleaning: If you find that your washer isn't cleaning larger loads properly, it could be because you're using the wrong cycle or your washer isn't sitting level.
Unusual Noises: Grinding, thumping, or squealing noises during operation can indicate a variety of mechanical issues. For instance, a squealing noise could point to belt problems and clicking might indicate an issue with your washer's lid switch or door lock.
Silent Spin Cycle: On the other hand, an unusually quiet spin cycle could be due to a malfunctioning lid switch.


Troubleshooting and Fixing a Whirlpool Washer That Won’t Spin
Based on the symptoms you are observing on your non-spinning washer, various underlying reasons may be at play:

Your Whirlpool Washer Won’t Empty or Spin: It can be frustrating when your washer seems stuck and there's still water inside after a cycle. To tackle this, you’ll need to check the drain hose of your washer to make sure it's not twisted, blocked, or bent in a way that stops the water from getting out.
Your Whirlpool Washer Drains but Won’t Spin: If your washer is good at getting rid of water but doesn't want to spin, there are two things to check. Look at the lid switch or door latch. If it's engaging, your washer thinks it's not safe to spin. Another possibility is a broken or displaced belt inside the machine.
Your Whirlpool Washer Does Not Spin at Full Speed:  If your washer is spinning slowly or stuttering, it's probably because of heavy or lopsided laundry loads. This can also make your washer move forward during a wash.


Things to Check on a Whirlpool Washer That Won’t Spin
Now that you know the suspects as to why your washer isn’t spinning, it's time to perform some quick troubleshooting. Start by examining these:

Is Your Washer Overloaded?
Begin by checking if you've overloaded your washer. Jamming too many clothes inside can hinder the spinning process. To fix this, simply remove some items and try the cycle again.

Are You Selecting the Right Cycle?
Using the correct cycle setting also helps the washer adapt to the specific demands of the load, including the spinning process. For example, opt for "bulky" when washing bedding or blankets.

Is Your Washer Level?
A balanced washer is crucial for effective spinning. An unlevel washer, with one or more feet not resting evenly on the ground, can lead to spinning problems. Use a level to check the appliance's balance and adjust the legs until the washer sits perfectly horizontal.

How to Troubleshoot the Lid Switch on a Whirlpool Washer That Won’t Spin
The lid switch in a top load Whirlpool washer is a safety feature that stops the machine from spinning when the lid is open. This small plastic component can be found either under the lid or on the top of the machine. You can manually activate it by gently pushing the tip of a screwdriver into it, to simulate the lid being closed. You should hear a distinct click from the switch whenever you close the lid shut. If you don't hear this click, the switch might need replacement. Follow these steps to inspect and test the lid switch:

Begin by disconnecting your washer from the power source.
Locate the lid switch, typically situated in the top right corner where the lid would close. On certain models, you might need to remove the top control panel or even the entire washer cabinet to access the lid switch.
Take out the screws holding the lid switch in place.
Carefully pull the lid switch from its position. The lid switch may still be attached due to wiring and retaining clips. Disconnect and remove these components.
To test the lid switch, use a multimeter to check for continuity. If the lid is closed (or you simulate it as closed), the multimeter should display continuity, often indicated by a beep or a reading close to zero ohms. A reading in this range confirms that the switch is functioning correctly. If there's no continuity, it's time to replace the lid switch.


How to Troubleshoot the Door Latch on a Whirlpool Washer That Won’t Spin
Like the lid switch on top load washers, the latch ensures the door on front load machines is securely locked during operation. It is usually behind the front panel of the washer, near the door frame. It consists of a latch assembly with a locking mechanism that engages with the door strike. If the door is not properly latched, the washer will not operate. This means that if the latch is defective, the washer will not spin. To access and check the door latch:

Unplug the washer or turn off the breaker to ensure safety.
Open the washer door. You might need to remove the front panel or access panel to reach the latch mechanism.
Remove the screws holding the latch assembly in place and lift it off its mounting bracket.
Disconnect the wires attached to the door latch assembly, and remove it from the washer. Some models may have a shield over the connectors that can be removed with a flathead screwdriver.
Test the door latch with a multimeter by first setting it to the continuity setting.
Look at the connector to identify the terminal pins for the door latch. Typically, there will be two or three pins that you'll be testing for continuity.
Touch the multimeter probes to the terminal pins on the door latch connector. You may need to refer to your owner's manual to know which pins to test. If testing a two-pin latch, place one probe on each pin. If there are more than two pins, you'll need to consult your washer's wiring diagram to know which pins to test for continuity.
If there is no continuity, the latch is defective and needs to be replaced.


How to Troubleshoot the Drive Belt on a Whirlpool Washer That Won’t Spin
The drive belt in a Whirlpool washer connects the motor to the drum, allowing it to spin. If the belt is worn, stretched, or broken, the drum won't spin properly. Signs of a failing belt include a squealing noise during operation or visible wear on the belt itself.

Unplug the washer from the power source, turn off the water supply to the washer, and disconnect the hoses to provide easier access to the rear washer panel.
Remove the back panel of the washer.
Check that the drive belt is secure and not frayed.
If you decide to replace the drive belt, turn the tub drive pulley, and the belt should fall off.
To install a new drive belt, put one end of the new belt around the motor pulley and place the other end on the tub drive pulley. Rotate the tub drive pulley to secure the new drive belt.
With the new drive belt fitted, reassemble the washer.


How to Troubleshoot the Drain Hose on a Whirlpool Washer That Won’t Spin
A kinked drain hose disrupts the flow of water, preventing your Whirlpool Washer from properly expelling from the washer's drum and unable to move into the spin cycle. To troubleshoot and install the hose correctly:

Start by inspecting the drain hose to identify any kinks or bends that might be obstructing water flow.
If you spot a kink in the drain hose, loosen the clamp that holds it in place at the washer's connection point. Carefully remove the kinked hose from the washer.
Replace the kinked hose with a new one. Ensure that the new drain hose is securely attached to your washer, and tighten the clamp to hold it firmly in place. To further prevent kinks, straighten the drain hose as much as possible.
If needed, use a U-shaped drain hose form (often included with the washer or available separately) to maintain the shape and position of the hose.
While troubleshooting the drain hose, also examine the drainpipe or utility sink where the hose expels the water. Make sure there are no blockages or clogs that could impede water drainage.


If you've gone through these troubleshooting steps and your Whirlpool washer still refuses to spin, it may be time to seek professional assistance. An experienced technician can diagnose and fix more complex issues, so that your washer can get back to its spinning best.

title: What do the Symbols on a Samsung Dryer Mean?
author: PartSelect Team
content:
PartSelect Blog
        
        
            All Topics
        
    

    
            
            
    

    

	
		
			Save
		
		
			
				
					What do the Symbols on a Samsung Dryer Mean?
					Identify flashing symbols and potential problems
				
				
					


    
        
            Post			
        
    

    
        
            Pin It			
        
    

    
        
            Share			
        
    

    
        
            Subscribe
        
    

				

				
					Page content+Common Samsung Dryer SymbolsSamsung Dryer Sensor DrySamsung Dryer Child LockSamsung Dryer Delay StartSamsung Dryer Filter ReminderSamsung Dryer Time RemainingSamsung Dryer Signal OffSamsung Dryer Mixed Load BellSamsung Dryer Vent CheckSamsung Dryer SteamSamsung Dryer Smart CareSamsung Dryer Smart ControlSamsung Dryer Wi-FiSamsung Dryer Cycle Progress+Common Samsung Dryer Error CodesSamsung Dryer "He" or "HE" error codeUnderstanding the symbols and indicators on your Samsung dryers can be confusing. Whether you are the proud owner of a brand-new Samsung dryer or you're trying to troubleshoot your dryer, understanding the meaning behind each symbol will help you make informed decisions and get the most out of your appliance. Each symbol represents a specific function or setting designed to optimize drying performance while preserving the integrity of your clothes. 

Common Samsung Dryer Symbols 
Navigate through this list of Samsung dryer symbols to find out what each one means, how to activate various features, and how to troubleshoot any potential problems.

Samsung Dryer Sensor Dry
SaveEmbed Image 
Source: Samsung Support
This symbol indicates that the Sensor Dry cycle is in progress. The Sensor Dry feature detects the moisture levels of the clothes inside the dryer. It will automatically adjust the time needed to complete the drying cycle based on the level of dryness you selected. Therefore, it is completely normal to notice the dryer time increase. The Sensor Dry feature helps to make the dryer more energy efficient and it prevents your clothes from heat damage. It is best to use this feature when you have an average to large laundry size. This is because there needs to be enough clothing items moving past the moisture sensor for the dryer to accurately detect the overall moisture levels. If the clothes are too few, then the dryer may be unable to detect the correct moisture levels and leave you with damp clothes at the end of the cycle.  

Samsung Dryer Child Lock
SaveEmbed Image 
Source: Samsung Support
This symbol is a sign that the Child Lock feature on your Samsung dryer is activated. It disables all the dryer buttons except for the Power button and the control knob. To activate the Child Lock feature, press and hold the two buttons on your control panel that have the “Child Lock” label underneath them, until the symbol lights up. To deactivate the Child Lock feature, simply press and hold the two buttons again until the symbol light switches off. 

Samsung Dryer Delay Start
SaveEmbed Image 
Source: Samsung Support
This symbol indicates that the Delay Start is activated. The Delay Start is used when you select a cycle but schedule it to begin at a later time. This feature allows you to select the most convenient time for your laundry to be done, for example, you can select a cycle to start while you are at work or running errands. To turn the Delay Start off, press and hold the buttons labeled “Time” and “Drying Level” at the same time for at least 3 seconds. 

Samsung Dryer Filter Reminder
SaveEmbed Image 
Source: Samsung Support
This symbol is the Filter Reminder. It lights up at the end of every cycle as a reminder to clean the dryer lint filter. It is recommended to clean the filter after each load to prevent lint from building up in the dryer vents, which restricts airflow in the dryer and reduces the heating capabilities of your dryer. On some Samsung dryer models, the Filter Reminder Icon will flash on and off in quick succession to draw your attention to it. If this icon does not switch off or it stays on for extended periods, it may be a sign that there is a control board error.  

Samsung Dryer Time Remaining
SaveEmbed Image 
Source: Samsung Support
This hourglass symbol indicates that the dryer is running on a timed cycle. The timed dry allows you to run a cycle and customize the length of the time that the cycle will run. The display panel will also show a series of numbers that indicate how much time is remaining until the end of the cycle. 

Samsung Dryer Signal Off
SaveEmbed Image
Source: Samsung Support
This symbol shows that the sounds that are played at the end of a cycle are turned off. This feature is useful if you do not want to be disturbed by the chiming sounds made by your dryer. To turn it on or off, simply press and hold the “Drum Light” button for 3 seconds. Alternatively, you can press and hold the “Options” button on your dryer and use the Navigation selector to select “Alarm”. Click “OK” and select the “Off” option. To turn the sound back on, simply follow these steps and select the “On” option. Depending on your Samsung dryer model, either of these two signs may be displayed, however they both indicate the same thing. 

Samsung Dryer Mixed Load Bell
SaveEmbed Image
Source: Samsung Support
This symbol represents the Mixed Load Bell. When you are running a load that contains a mix of heavy and light items, this feature will notify you when the load reaches 80% dryness. It is recommended to pause the cycle and remove the lighter/dry items before continuing with the rest of the load. However, if you do not pause the cycle, the dryer will continue as normal. To turn this feature on, simply hold down the Mixed Load Bell button for 3 seconds.

Samsung Dryer Vent Check
SaveEmbed Image
Source: Samsung Support
This symbol indicates that the exhaust vent needs to be cleaned. It is a safety feature that will light up when it detects that the vent is 60% clogged. Once the vent is 80% clogged, the Vent Check symbol will start blinking on and off. A blocked vent could lead to longer drying times, poor heating, and even a fire hazard. To check the vent pipe, simply disconnect it from the back of the dryer and check for any visible obstructions. Use a soft, flexible brush to remove any build-up, or call in a professional if you are unable to clear it yourself.

Samsung Dryer Steam
SaveEmbed Image
Source: Samsung Support
This symbol is a sign that the Steam feature in your dryer is active.  This feature works the same way as a traditional clothes steamer, by spraying water on your clothes during the drying cycle to remove odors, and static and to smooth out any wrinkles. You can turn on this feature when you are selecting a drying cycle for your clothes. 

Samsung Dryer Smart Care
SaveEmbed Image
Source: Samsung Support
This icon is displayed when the Smart Care feature is enabled. Smart Care is a diagnostic tool used to find out any potential problems that your dryer may be experiencing. When you select the Smart Care option, a code will be displayed. Enter the code into the Samsung Smart Dryer app to find out what the code means and how to troubleshoot the issue. You can also use your phone camera to quickly scan the code. This feature does not require the use of Wi-Fi.

Samsung Dryer Smart Control
SaveEmbed Image
Source: Samsung Support
This symbol indicates that the Smart Control feature is activated. It allows you to monitor your dryer remotely. You can use this feature when you are out running errands, or you are at work. Using the SmartThings app, you can check the cycle settings and the time remaining until the end of the cycle. To use the SmartControl feature, open the SmartThings app and click the “Home” option. Select your dryer and look for the information you are interested in.  

Samsung Dryer Wi-Fi
SaveEmbed Image 
Source: Samsung Support
This Wi-Fi icon indicates that the dryer is successfully connected to the internet. Wi-Fi connectivity is available on all Samsung Smart Dryers. When the Wi-Fi icon is lit up, you can use the SmartThings app to monitor your dryer remotely or control various cycle settings. You can also receive drying cycle suggestions to optimize your laundry days based on your previous usage history. 

Samsung Dryer Cycle Progress
SaveEmbed Image 
Source: Samsung Support
These symbols represent which part of the cycle the dryer is currently on. For example, the dryer may be currently sanitizing the laundry, or it may be on the wrinkle control part. These icons can help you tell how much time is left before the laundry cycle is complete.

Common Samsung Dryer Error Codes

Samsung Dryer "do" Error CodeThis error code indicates that the door of the dryer is not securely closed or the door switch may be malfunctioning. Before beginning any repairs, first try to close the door firmly, as this normally fixes the issues. However, if the problem persists, inspect the door switch area in case something is blocking the door from closing properly, or preventing the switch from detecting that the door is shut, such as lint or built-up residue. Use a soft cloth and rubbing alcohol to clean the area thoroughly.
If you have tried to close the door and clean the door switch area and the error code is still displayed then the door switch may be malfunctioning either due to physical damage or an electrical fault. You will need to remove the door switch from the dryer and visually inspect it for visible signs of wear. You can also use a multimeter set to the "ohms" setting to check for continuity. If it is faulty, you will need a replacement door switch to fix your Samsung dryer.

Samsung Dryer "dF" Error CodeThe dF error code signifies a door circuit failure. This code is typically displayed when the door switch is faulty. Locate the door switch around the dryer door frame and inspect the door switch for any signs of damage or wear. If the switch appears damaged or doesn't click when you press it, it may need to be replaced. Using a multimeter set to continuity to test the switch for electrical failure is also recommended. Sometimes, the issue may be with the wiring connected to the door switch. Make sure the wires are securely connected and not damaged. You will need to replace the wire harness if it is no longer in good working condition.

Samsung Dryer "Od" Error CodeThe Od error ode on a Samsung dryer typically indicates that the dryer is taking longer than normal to dry clothes. This could be due to several factors, including:

Clogged lint filter: A clogged lint filter restricts the airflow in the dryer and reduces the dryer's heating abilities, leading to longer drying times. It is recommended to clean your lint filter after every laundry load.
Blocked vent system:  A blocked or restricted vent system will also prevent hot air from freely flowing through the dryer and cause longer drying times. Check the vent hose and exterior vent opening for any obstructions and clear them if necessary.
Overloaded dryer:  Overloading the dryer with too many clothes prevents heat from moving evenly throughout the clothes, forcing the dryer to run for longer. Try reducing the size of the load and running multiple smaller loads instead.
Incorrect dryer settings:  Using the wrong drying cycle or temperature setting for the type of fabric being dried can also lead to excessive drying times. Check your user manual and select the appropriate settings for your laundry.



Samsung Dryer "FE" Error CodeThis error code is displayed when there is a problem with the power supply. It could mean that the dryer is not receiving adequate power or that there's an issue with the electrical connection. Electric Samsung dryers require a properly grounded 220/240-volt branch circuit, and a 30 amp circuit breaker, while Samsung gas dryers require a 110-volt, three-prong, grounded electrical outlet that is positioned close to the power cord. If there is an issue with the power supply in your home, it is recommended to call in a professional technician or electrician to handle the problem. However, if your dryer is receiving the power that it needs and this code is displayed, it may simply be a control board glitch. Turn the dryer off at the circuit breaker for 3-5 minutes before turning it back on again to fix the problem.

Samsung Dryer "tS" or "tO" Error CodeThis error code indicates a problem with the temperature sensor in your dryer. This error can occur if the temperature sensor is faulty or if there's an issue with the wiring or connections related to the sensor. 

First inspect the sensor for any signs of wear or damage. 
Next, set your multimeter to the resistance or ohms setting.
Connect the multimeter probes to the terminals of the temperature sensor. Make sure the probes make good contact with the terminals.
The multimeter should display a resistance reading. Typically, a working temperature sensor should show a specific resistance value within a certain range. Refer to your dryer's manual for the correct resistance value. If the reading falls out of the correct range, then you will need to replace the sensor.


Samsung Dryer "He" or "HE" error code
This error code on either a Samsung gas or electric dryer usually indicates a problem with the heating element. It stands for "Heating Element Error." It means that the dryer is not heating properly or not heating at all. This could be due to issues such as a faulty heating element, a defective thermostat, or problems with the wiring. 

Gas Dryer: First check that the cut-off valve for the gas supply is fully open. If this does not resolve the issue, you will need to check the entire gas heating system. It is recommended to call a professional repair technician to do so. 
Electric Dryer: First check that the circuit breaker for the dryer has not tripped. If not, you will need to inspect the dryer's heating element or any damage or malfunction. If the element is faulty, you will need to replace it before you can resume using your dryer.



Samsung Dryer "bE" Error CodeThis error code indicates that there is a stuck button on the control panel. This means that one of the buttons on the control panel is being held down or is stuck in the pressed position. This can prevent the dryer from working properly and it will make it difficult for you to input commands because the dryer thinks a button is being pressed continuously. To resolve this issue, try pressing each button on the control panel to ensure none of them are stuck. If you find a button that feels stuck, try gently tapping it to see if it releases. If you are unable to free the button, then you may need to replace the control panel.

We hope that this guide will help you understand your Samsung dryer better. It is important to note that the appearance of icons may vary slightly, and some icons may not be available for certain dryer models. For model-specific details, it is always recommended to refer back to your dryer's user manual whenever you are in doubt. If your dryer is acting up and you need a new replacement part, browse our list of genuine OEM Samsung dryer parts.

title: How to Remove a Dishwasher in 8 Easy Steps
author: PartSelect Team
content:
PartSelect Blog
        
        
            All Topics
        
    

    
            
            
    

    

	
		
			Save
		
		
			
				
					How to Remove a Dishwasher in 8 Easy Steps
					A Start-to-Finish DIY Guide
				
				
					


    
        
            Post			
        
    

    
        
            Pin It			
        
    

    
        
            Share			
        
    

    
        
            Subscribe
        
    

				

				
					Page contentReasons for Removing a Dishwasher+FAQs About Removing a DishwasherCan I remove my dishwasher by myself?What should I do if water leaks during the removal process?How do I dispose of my old dishwasher?+How to Remove a DishwasherTools Needed to Remove a DishwasherStep 1: Turn Off the PowerStep 2: Turn Off the Water SupplyStep 3: Disconnect the Water Supply HoseStep 4: Disconnect the Drain HoseStep 5: Remove the Mounting BracketsStep 6: Lower the LegsStep 7: Slide Out the DishwasherStep 8: Final DisconnectionsConsidering an upgrade or dealing with dishwasher issues? You might need to remove it, and it's a task you can handle without professional help. Our guide makes it easy, guiding you through safely disconnecting the water and power connections and using basic tools like a wrench, screwdriver, and pliers to remove the unit from below your countertop.

Reasons for Removing a Dishwasher
Sometimes, you might find yourself needing to take out your dishwasher, and there are a few good reasons why:

Upgrading to a New Model: If you're eyeing that latest dishwasher model, it might be time to say goodbye to your old one and welcome a new, modern unit into your home.
Maintenance or Repair: Dishwashers don't last forever. They can start to show their age, with parts wearing out or even breaking. Removing it is necessary for deep cleaning, troubleshooting, or repairing parts that are not easily accessible while it is installed.
Water Damage or Mold: Water where it shouldn't be is a big no-no. If you spot leaks, water damage to your cabinets, or mold around your dishwasher, it's important to pull it out and fix the issue. Leaving it be can cause more damage over time.
Relocation: Are you moving to a new place? You might need to remove your dishwasher either to take it with you because you really like it, or because the one waiting for you in the new place isn't up to scratch.


FAQs About Removing a Dishwasher
If you're planning to remove your dishwasher, you might have some questions. Here, we've answered the most common ones to help you get ready for the next steps, where we'll show you exactly how to do it.

Can I remove my dishwasher by myself?
Yes, you can! If you feel confident in following step-by-step directions and know your way around basic tools, you can uninstall your dishwasher on your own. However, if you’re unsure about any part of the process, especially when it comes to electrical or plumbing connections, it might be a good idea to call in a pro.

What should I do if water leaks during the removal process?
Keep a bucket or towels ready to catch any drips. If a leak occurs, ensure the water supply valve is fully turned off and clean up any spills right away to avoid damaging your floor or cabinets.

How do I dispose of my old dishwasher?
Recycling is a great option. Check with your local waste management to see if they take large appliances like dishwashers. If your dishwasher is still in working condition, you might also think about donating it or selling it secondhand.

How to Remove a Dishwasher
You're now set to uninstall your dishwasher. With the right tools in hand, you're about to see how surprisingly straightforward this process can be.
Tools Needed to Remove a Dishwasher

Bucket and Old Towels
Wrench
Screwdriver
Pliers
Optional: Furniture Sliders or Dolly


Step 1: Turn Off the Power
Since you’ll be working with electrical wires, it’s important to turn off the power to the dishwasher. Head to your circuit breaker box and switch off the breaker for your dishwasher. To be sure you've turned off the right one, try turning on the dishwasher; if it stays off, you can proceed to the next step.

Step 2: Turn Off the Water Supply
You'll need to stop the water flow to your dishwasher. Find the water shutoff valve connected to your dishwasher's water line—this is usually located under your sink. Gently turn the knob clockwise until it stops. Be careful not to overtighten it, as it could break.

Step 3: Disconnect the Water Supply Hose
Find the water supply hose that connects your dishwasher to the shutoff valve, usually located under the sink. Check the hose for leaks or rust. If it looks worn out, you'll want to change it to a replacement hose later when you're reinstalling the dishwasher. Get an adjustable wrench to unscrew the water line. Keep a bucket and some towels ready just in case water drips out. Then, with pliers, gently pull off the dishwasher's drain hose and put the end into the bucket to avoid water leaking out onto the floor.

Step 4: Disconnect the Drain Hose
The next hose to disconnect is the drain hose, which links your dishwasher to either the sink or a garbage disposal unit, often through an air gap. Find the hose, loosen the clamp that holds it in place, and disconnect it. Once disconnected, aim the end of the hose into the bucket.

Step 5: Remove the Mounting Brackets
Your dishwasher is kept in place by some brackets that connect it to the bottom of your countertop. This stops it from shaking or moving when it's running. Just open the dishwasher door to find these brackets and unscrew them from the countertop. You can either leave the brackets attached to the dishwasher or remove them completely.

Step 6: Lower the Legs
Before you can move your dishwasher, you will need to lower it by unscrewing the legs. Depending on the make and model of your dishwasher, you will either have legs that can be lowered straight away, or you’ll need to access them by removing a faceplate. The faceplate can usually be removed by unclipping it or unthreading its mounting screws.

When you have access to the legs, lower them down by twisting them clockwise until they are as low as you can get them. This will create a gap between it and the countertop, making it easier to pull out.

Step 7: Slide Out the Dishwasher
Gently pull the dishwasher away from its cavity. It’s great if someone can help you out here to make sure you don't drop it or pull too hard. Remember, there are water and power lines still attached, so be careful. Using furniture sliders or a dolly can also help with this step. Lift the dishwasher slightly as you pull it to avoid scratching your floor.

Step 8: Final Disconnections
With the dishwasher partway out, you’ll find it easier to see and reach any remaining hoses or wires. Disconnect these carefully, making sure your dishwasher is entirely free and ready to be moved completely.

With the dishwasher out of the way, what's next? Depending on its condition, consider repairing, selling, donating, recycling, or responsibly disposing of it. Don't forget to prepare the space for any new installations. And if you're eager for more renovation projects, find your next venture in our extensive collection of home improvement guides.

title: How to Quickly Fix the Maytag Washer LF Error Code
author: PartSelect Team
content:
PartSelect Blog
        
        
            All Topics
        
    

    
            
            
    

    

	
		
			Save
		
		
			
				
					How to Quickly Fix the Maytag Washer LF Error Code
					Troubleshoot Washer Water Supply Problems With Ease
				
				
					


    
        
            Post			
        
    

    
        
            Pin It			
        
    

    
        
            Share			
        
    

    
        
            Subscribe
        
    

				

				
					Page content+Water Supply Taps are ClosedHow to Open the Water Taps to Clear the Maytag Washer LF Error+Incorrectly Installed Drain HoseHow to Correctly Position the Drain Hose to Clear the Maytag Washer LF Error Code+Faulty Inlet HosesHow to Clean and Replace the Inlet Hoses to Clear Maytag Washer LF Error +Clogged Water Inlet FiltersHow to Clean the Water Inlet Filters to Clear the Maytag Washer LF Error Code+Faulty Water Inlet ValveHow to Replace a Faulty Water Inlet Valve to Clear the Maytag LF Error CodeLow Water PressureHow to Test Water Pressure Levels for Your Maytag WasherThe LF error code on a Maytag washer stands for "Long Fill". This means that the washer is taking too long to fill with water or not filling at all. The code may also be displayed as F8 E1 or Lo FL depending on your washer model, however, they mean the same thing. The LF error is normally caused by a problem with the water supply, low water pressure, faulty water inlet valves, clogged inlet screens, or an incorrectly installed drain hose. This guide will walk you through identifying and troubleshooting the problem so you can get your washer running again in no time.

Water Supply Taps are Closed
Check if the taps supplying water to the washer are fully turned on. The water supply tap is a manual valve typically found on the wall behind the washer. When it is open, it allows water to flow to the washer. If it is not completely open, water will be unable to fill the washer during the wash cycle, resulting in the LF error.

How to Open the Water Taps to Clear the Maytag Washer LF Error

Begin by disconnecting the washing machine from the power source.
Pull the washer forward if you need to gain better access to the taps.
Turn each valve handle or knob in a counterclockwise direction to open it.
Check for any leaks around the valve or hoses.
If you find that the water pressure is too high or too low, adjust the valve slightly to achieve the desired water flow.
Reconnect the washer to the power source and run a short cycle to confirm that the LF code is no longer displayed.


Incorrectly Installed Drain Hose
The drain is responsible for carrying water out of the washer at the end of a cycle. However, if it is not properly installed, it can affect the water flowing into the washer. If the end of the drain hose is inserted too far into the standpipe or drain, it will cause a siphoning or vacuum effect. This means that water may continuously drain from the washer, which can prevent the washer from properly filling with water. 

How to Correctly Position the Drain Hose to Clear the Maytag Washer LF Error Code

Adjust Drain Hose Height: The drain hose should be positioned above the water level inside the washer. If it's too low, water can siphon out.
Install a Standpipe Air Gap: There should be an air gap between the end of the drain hose and the standpipe. If there is no air gap you can purchase one from your local hardware store and install it yourself. 
Use a Drain Hose Restraint: A drain hose restraint keeps the hose secure and can prevent the hose from moving and slipping too far into the standpipe.
Use the Correct Drain Hose Length: A long hose can increase the chance of kinks and blockages which can affect the flow of water.
Pull the Washer Forward: Avoid pushing your washer too close to the wall as this may compromise the drain hose. Wherever possible, maintain a straight path for the hose to avoid sharp bends which can restrict water flow.
 

Faulty Inlet Hoses
The inlet hoses are flexible, rubber tubes that connect your washing machine to the water supply. These hoses allow water to flow into the washer for each wash cycle. There is one hose for hot water and one for cold water. If these hoses are kinked or damaged, water will be unable to flow into the washer and fill it up at the appropriate time. 

How to Clean and Replace the Inlet Hoses to Clear Maytag Washer LF Error 

Ensure the washing machine is unplugged from the power outlet to prevent the risk of electric shock.
 Locate the water supply valves connected to the washing machine and turn them off by turning the handles clockwise. These valves are typically located on the wall behind the washer or under a nearby sink.
Carefully pull the washing machine away from the wall to create space to access the back panel. 
Locate the inlet hoses which are connected to the back of the washing machine. They are usually color-coded, with the hot water hose being red and the cold water hose being blue. 
Disconnect the hoses from the washer and carefully examine the entire length of each hose for any signs of wear, cracks, or leaks.
If you notice any damage, you will need to replace the hose to fix the LF error.
Inspect the hoses for any debris or buildup that could restrict water flow and carefully remove any blockages.
Once clear, reconnect the hoses to the washing machine and turn on the water supply.
Reconnect your washer to power to complete the repair.


Clogged Water Inlet Filters
The water inlet filters are protective coverings that prevent dirt and debris from flowing into the washing machine. They are found where the water hoses connect to the back of the washing machine. It is common for these filters to get clogged over time. This buildup restricts the flow of water into the washing machine, reducing the amount of water that enters the tub during the filling cycle and resulting in the LF error. If the filters are excessively clogged, water may not enter the washer at all. It is important to regularly clean them to ensure your washer runs optimally and it is recommended to replace the inlet filters every 6 months. You can browse our selection of Maytag inlet filters if it is time to replace yours. 

How to Clean the Water Inlet Filters to Clear the Maytag Washer LF Error Code

Ensure the washing machine is unplugged to ensure your safety.
Shut off the water supply valves connected to the washing machine to prevent water from flowing while you're working on it.
Disconnect the water supply hoses from the back of the washer. 
Look inside the inlet valves on the back of the washer to locate the mesh filter.  
Carefully remove the inlet filters. You may need a pair of needle-nose pliers.
Run the filters under warm water and use a soft brush to remove any remaining buildup. Once clean, return the filters to their correct positions.  
If the filters are no longer usable, discard them and install the new ones.
Reconnect the water supply hoses and turn on the water supply. Ensure there are no leakages.
Turn your washer back on and run a short cycle to check if the code has been cleared.


Faulty Water Inlet Valve
The water inlet valve is responsible for controlling the flow of water into the washer. During the wash cycle, the inlet valve opens and allows water to fill the drum. When the correct level of water is reached, the inlet valve closes. If the valve is damaged or faulty it may be unable to allow water to freely flow into the washer. If it is faulty, you must replace the inlet valve to clear the LF error code.

How to Replace a Faulty Water Inlet Valve to Clear the Maytag LF Error Code

Unplug the washer, turn off the water supply, and pull the washing machine forward for easier access.
Disconnect the water hoses from the back of the washing machine.
Remove the back panel of the washer to access the inlet valves.
Disconnect the wiring from the water inlet valve.
Remove the mounting hardware that secures the valve in place, and carefully pull it out of the washer.  
Place the new water inlet valve inside the washer and secure it using the appropriate screws.
Reconnect the wires to the new valve.
Reattach the back panel to the washer and ensure it is fixed in place.
Connect each water supply hose to the new inlet valve.
Plug the washer back in and test that the new valve is working correctly.


Low Water Pressure
The water pressure in your home needs to be adequate for the washer to fill properly. Low water pressure can cause the washer to take longer to fill or not to fill at all. If the valves are open, and there are no leaks in the hoses, you should test your home's water supply using a water pressure test gauge. Typically, water pressure requirements for washing machines range from 20 psi to 120 psi. 

How to Test Water Pressure Levels for Your Maytag Washer

Identify the water supply valve that provides water to your washing machine. It is usually located on the wall behind the washer or under a sink nearby.
Turn off other water fixtures in your home that may be using water, such as faucets, showers, or toilets. 
Attach the pressure gauge to the water supply valve.
Slowly turn on the water supply valve to allow water to flow through the pressure gauge. Monitor the pressure gauge to observe the water pressure reading.
Check the pressure reading. If the pressure is low, you may need to call in a plumber or a professional technician to look for any pipe blockages or issues with the plumbing lines.


Encountering the LF error code in your Maytag washer can be frustrating! By first addressing potential problems such as water supply issues or blockages, you can easily troubleshoot your way through this error. However, if you are in doubt it is always best to call in a professional. Remember, regular maintenance, including cleaning water inlet filters and inspecting hoses, is key to optimizing your washer's performance and reducing the chance of any future problems. 

				

				
					


    
        
            Post			
        
    

    
        
            Pin It
